attributes.title: Testing Different Mortality Salience Manipulations
attributes.description: We will test three different mortality salience manipulations.

q3.value:
Recent replication attempts of Terror Management Theory (TMT) did not succeed (Sætrevik and Sjåstad, 2019; Klein et al., 2019). One possible reason for these unsuccessful replications might be ineffective manipulations. So, the question remains that if the TMT manipulations are ineffective at all or if there are some working manipulations to study death anxiety. In this study, we will test three different MS manipulations that were claimed to be working in the literature (Cox et al., 2009; Kesebir, 2014; Luo, Shi, Yang, Wang, and Han, 2014) and compare these manipulations to identify an effective MS manipulation. 

In the first MS manipulation, Cox et al. (2009) asked participants to complete the Fear of Death Scale (Templar, 1970) or questions that are related to public speaking. In the second manipulation, Kesebir (2014) asked participants to search for three images on the web (e.g., Google images); either "graveyard" or "mug" photographs, and upload their links to the survey. In the third MS manipulation, Luo et al., (2014) asked participants to rate twenty-eight statements either on the negative emotions related to death or on the negative emotions unrelated to death. 

After having different MS manipulations, participants will rate 5 questions related to death anxiety or unpleasant feelings as the first set of manipulation checks (Chen et al., 2019; Lou et al., 2014). Then they complete the death-thought accessibility measure (Greenberg, Pyszczynski, Solomon, Simon, and Breus, 1994) as the second set of manipulation checks. 

After each manipulation, the participants will also complete an additional survey. The survey is designed to measure the association between moral emotions (shame, guilt, anger, contempt, disgust, and condemning) and violation of moral motives in a different relational context. These questions are unrelated to the scope of the current study and will not be analyzed as part of this project. A new pre-registered project is created for this additional survey.

q4.value:
We hypothesize that (1) death-thought accessibility and death anxiety will be higher when participants google for "graveyard" images than when they google "mug" images; (2) death-thought accessibility and death anxiety will be higher in participants who completed the Fear of Death Scale compared to the participants who completed fear of public speaking questions; (3) death-thought accessibility and death anxiety will be higher in participants who rated statements of negative emotions related to death compared to participants who rated statements of negative emotions unrelated to death. 

We hypothesize that experimental and control conditions will not differ in terms of positive and negative affect scores (PANAS). 

We don't have any specific hypothesis on the interaction between different MS manipulations, however, we will explore data for any differences in effects of these three manipulations to find which of the tested MS manipulation work best.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Three MS manipulations will be tested with different human participants, thus the study is between-subjects design. There will be two conditions in each manipulation (mortality salience vs. control).  

The design of this project is between subjects. The participants entering the survey will first sign the inform consent and then will be randomly assigned to one of the three experimental sets (i.e., one of the three MS manipulations). Then each participant will be informed about the specifics of the experimental design and then will be randomly assigned to MS or control group. 

After the necessities of experimental or control conditions are completed each participant will get two different manipulation check sets. In the first manipulation check, they will rate 5 statements about death-related anxiety and unpleasant feelings. In the second set of manipulation checks, participants will complete a death-thought accessibility task.

Then, participants will read 12 vignettes. Each vignette describes a protagonist violates the moral motives of a social relationship. Then each vignette follows with a series of questions about moral emotions (i.e., shame guilt, contempt, anger, disgust, condemning) and approach-avoidance motivations. We will not analyze this within-participants section of the experiment within the scope of this project. 

At the end, participants will complete demographic questions Finally, all participants will be briefed.

All participants will be randomly assigned any between participants groups and all questions within the scales will be randomly presented.

q9.value:
Each participant entering the online survey will be randomly assigned to one of the three different mortality salience manipulation experiments after accepting informed consent. Here we use simple randomization where each participant has an equal chance to enter one of the experiments. 

After entering the experiment, all participants again will be randomly assigned into either experimental condition (MS manipulation) or control condition. Here again, each participant will have an equal chance to enter either experimental or control conditions. 

Once the participants complete their task in experimental or control conditions, will answer PANAS, delay anagram task, manipulation check questions, and death-thought accessibility task, respectively. However, all statements within these scales or tasks will be randomly presented. 

The vignettes and embedded questions will be also randomly presented.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
All individuals aged above 18 and actively using the internet will be reached to participate in the study. University students will be reached via their course instructors and will be given course credit for their participation. Non-student individuals will be reached via social media including Twitter, Facebook, and dictionaries (e.g., https://eksisozluk.com). 

The participants who were very slow or very fast to complete the survey (-3 and +3 z-scores distant from the mean duration time in Qualtrics) will be excluded from the study. Further, participants who fail to complete manipulation questions and manipulation check questions will be excluded from the analysis.

q13.value: The MS manipulations include two conditions per experiment, thus we used GPower to determine the minimum sample size to detect Cohen's d = .05 (medium) effect size by 95% power. Power analyses suggested 630 participants, 105 participants per cell. Assuming the possible dropouts we will attempt to recruit up to 650 individuals.

q14.value: From the tested MS manipulations, only Luo et al. (2014) reported their manipulation check test results, thus first we used their results to estimate the effect size and found Cohen's d = .79. The GPower recommended 43 participants per cell (total 86 participants per experiment) to detect d = .79 effect size and 95% power. However, since the last replication effects failed to replicate the MS manipulations, we decided to reduce the minimum effect size of interest in this study and determined sample size to detect a medium effect size (Cohen's d = .50). A power analysis recommended 105 participants per cell (630 total) to detect an effect size of Cohen's d = .50 at p smaller than .05 and for 95% power.

q15.value: We will stop data collection once 6500 individuals completed the survey before April 15. If we cannot recruit 6500 participants until April 15, we will stop data collection and analyze the collected data.

question.value:
We manipulated death anxiety in three different experiments. Each experiment tested a different manipulation method and include two conditions (MS vs. control). 

In the first experiment (Kesebir, 2014), participants in the experimental MS condition will read "GRAVEYARD" on the computer screen and will be asked to google this word and copy/paste three links of websites depicting an image of a graveyard. In the control condition, the participants will read "MUG" on the screen and will be asked to google this word and copy/past three links of websites depicting an image of a mug. Then the participants will complete Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS; Watson, Clark, and Tellegen,1998). After that participants will complete a 5-minute task (of delay). In this task, participants will solve a very simple anagram. 

In the second experiment (Cox et al., 2009), the participants in the experimental MS condition will complete Fear of Death Anxiety Scale (Templar, 1970) and the participants in the control conditions will complete an identical scale that measures fear of public speaking. Then the participants will complete PANAS (Watson, and, Tellegen,1998). After that participants will complete a 5-minute task (of delay). In this task, participants will solve a very simple anagram. 

In the third experiment  (Luo, Shi, Yang, Wang and, Han, 2014), the participants in the experimental MS condition will rate twenty-eight statements on negative emotions related to death and participants in the control condition will rate twenty-eight statements on negative emotions (unrelated to death). Then the participants will complete PANAS (Watson, Clark, and Tellegen, 1998). After that participants will complete a 5-minute task (of delay). In this task, participants will solve a very simple anagram. 

After completing these tasks, all participants will be asked how difficult the tasks were and then they will complete two separate manipulation check tasks. In the first task all participants will rate 5 questions (see the survey questions on the attached document) adapted from Lou at al., (2014) on a 10-point Likert type scale (1 refers to Not at all and 10 refers to Extremely). In the second task, participants will complete the death-thought accessibility scale (Greenberg, Pyszczynski, Solomon, Simon, and Breus, 1994).

Positive and Negative Affect Schedule. This scale was prepared by Watson, Clark, and Tellegen (1998). The scale consists of 20 different adjectives. It will be asked participants to indicate how they feel close to these 20 adjectives on a 5-point Likert type scale. 

Manipulation check questions (Cox et al., 2009; Lou et al., 2014). Participants will rate 5 questions (see the survey questions on the attached document) on a 10-point Likert type scale (1 refers to Not at all and 10 refers to Extremely). Three of the questions are about death-related anxiety and 2 of them are about unpleasant feelings.  

Death-Thought Accessibility. This measurement tool was prepared by Greenberg, Pyszczynski, Solomon, Simon, and Breus (1994). There are 25 incomplete words. 7 of them can be completed by both death-related and neutral words. Others can be completed by only neutral words. 

Vignettes and related questions: A protagonist in each vignette violates some moral motive of a specific social-relational situation. The vignettes and questions were adopted from Dalgar (2019) and measures how participants evaluate the emotional and motivational condition of the protagonist after each vignette. 

Demographic questions; date of birth, sex, educational level, educational level of individual's own mother, monthly income range, and perceived socioeconomic state, religious and political orientations. 

Delay task which consists of anagram puzzle and related question about the difficulty of the puzzle was prepared by Doğulu (2017).

A principal component analysis with 5 items of manipulation check that was adapted from Lou et al. (2014) will be performed to test if death anxiety-related questions forms a component. If they load onto the same component, the variable will be computed by having mean of these three questions. 

Seven words in the death-thought accessibility scale will be used to calculate how much death-related words were formed. The frequency of death-related words will be computed. 

Positive affect and negative affect variables will be computed by the mean of the related items.

To test the effectiveness of each manipulation, separate independent samples t-tests will be performed for both death thought accessibility and death anxiety for three different manipulations. 

To test if experimental and control conditions will differ in terms of positive and negative affect three independent samples t-tests will be performed. 

Two separate 2 (experimental vs. control) x 3 (Manipulation 1 vs. Manipulation 2 vs. Manipulation 3) between-subjects analysis of variance where death-thought accessibility and death anxiety are the dependent variables. This will compare which manipulation works more effectively, thus we are interested if manipulation*condition interaction.

q21.value: Since the number of independent samples t-tests for two manipulation checks for three different manipulations will be performed, we adjusted p-value by dividing .05 by 6. We will accept p smaller than .008 as a criterion for manipulations to succeed.

q22.value: Data of participants who met the inclusion criteria will be used in all analyses.

q23.value: Pairwise deletion will be used to exclude participants with missing values from the analyses.

q24.value: The interaction of manipulation type and experimental conditions will be exploratory part of the study.

attributes.title: Human Factors and Artificial Intelligence Around Healthcare: A Scoping Review
attributes.description: How human factors journals have been involved in improving healthcare artificial intelligence systems

q1.value: Human Factors and Artificial Intelligence Around Healthcare: A 10-year scoping review

q3.value:
The Purpose of the Study:
• To identify and map the available evidence supporting the involvement of Human Factor society in healthcare technology particularly artificial intelligence
• To identify and analyze research gaps and potentially encourage the Human Factors researchers to contribute towards artificial intelligence within the healthcare industry

Research Question:
How Human Factors researchers have contributed towards the development of artificial intelligence to safeguard healthcare and what can be the possible future trend?

q4.value: HFE researchers have not been contributing enough in the field of Healthcare and AI

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
To conduct this scoping review, we will list all peer-reviewed human factors journals and conferences. We will refer to the "Scopus Master List" and "Scimago Journal & Country Rank" (SJR) to finalize our list of journals. This list will then be reviewed and verified by the senior researcher (Dr. O. A) and university librarian.

We will follow two different strategies, each specifically designed for journals and conferences.
To search within journals, we follow the PRISMA-ScR guidelines and utilize the following databases to conduct our search:
• Web of Science • PubMed
• Medline
• PubMed Central • IEEE Xplore
However, to be consistent, we will report our findings (number of papers extracted) based on each journal (e.g., 10 articles from PubMed).

The authors will develop and refine a search strategy in collaboration with our institution’s librarian to narrow down the scope. We will use free texts and Mesh terms to search Journal papers. We will then group the query keywords and combine them using an AND/OR operator to identify all studies published by human factors journals in the domain of healthcare and artificial intelligence.
We will use the following query to search relevant peer-reviewed journal papers using artificial intelligence technology:
"Artificial intelligence" OR "machine learning" OR "deep learning" OR "natural language processing" OR "text mining" OR "robot*" OR "expert system" OR "fuzzy" OR "neural network" OR "artificial neural network"

Inclusion Criteria:
• The article is published within the last 10 years
• The article is published in the English language
• The article is either a full, a short paper or an extended abstract
• The article is peer-reviewed
• The article is published in one of our targeted journals
• The study implements artificial intelligence technology within the healthcare domain. • The article is published before 2009
• The article is published in a foreign language
• The article does not implement any artificial intelligence technology
• The article does not address any issue related to healthcare
• The article is abstract without an extended version

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q1.value: When seeing stigma creates paternalism: Learning about disadvantage leads to perceptions of incompetence

q3.value: This study examines how the different ways of discussing experiences of stigmatization affect people's perceptions of stigmatized individuals. Specifically, we examine the consequences of focusing exclusively on difficulties associated with experiences of stigmatized vs. focusing on stigmatized people's resilience in the face of their difficulties.

q4.value:
Our predictions are as follows:
We predict that participants who focus on a stigmatized target's difficulties will view the target as more helpless and less competent and also report less admiration and less interest in affiliating with the target, relative to those in the control condition and those who focus on the target's resilience.

We predict that participants who focus on a stigmatized target's resilience will view the target as more competent and report more admiration and more interest in affiliating with the target, relative to those in the control condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study includes one between subjects factor with 3 groups:  Difficulties-focus, Resilience-focus, and Control. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of these three conditions by the survey software.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will recruit 600 White participants via Turk Prime. 

Because of recent concerns about data quality issues on MTurk, we will also include the following questions to exclude participants.  Participants will be randomly assigned to see two of the following four questions:


1.  John couldn't see the stage with Billy in front of him because he is so [short/tall]. Who is so [short/tall]? 
Answers: John/Billy.

2.  Pete envies Martin [because/although] he is very successful. Who is very successful? 
Answers: Martin/Pete.

3.  The lawyer asked the witness a question, but he was reluctant to [answer/repeat] it . Who was reluctant to [answer/repeat] the question? 
Answers: The witness/the lawyer.

4.  The delivery truck zoomed by the school bus because it was going so [fast/slow]. What was going so [fast/slow]? 
Answers: The truck/the bus

We will exclude participants who do not answer both questions correctly.  In addition, we will ask participants their age at the beginning of the survey, and their year of birth at the end of the survey.  We will exclude participants who provide non-matching entries. (i.e. those who provide a year of birth inconsistent with their reported age).

question.value: We are manipulating the ways in which participants focus on stigmatized individuals' experiences: there are three conditions: a difficulties-focus condition, a resilience-focus condition, and a control condition

Our primary dependent measures are participants’ ratings of the target’s traits related to helplessness and competence.

	Helplessness: victim, incapable, in need of help, weak, needs support
	Competence: empowered, strong, intelligent, determined, able to help others, has a lot to offer

On a secondary basis, we will also examine feelings of admiration for the target and their willingness to affiliate with the target in competence-relevant situations. These will be measured with the following items:

Admiration: admiring, fond, inspired, proud, respectful


Affiliation: 

•	How interested would you be in working on an intensive, three-month project with Tyrone?

•	How interested would you be in joining a work group with Tyrone?

•	How interested would you be asking Tyrone to provide feedback on a report you wrote?

•	How interested would you be in having Tyrone as a partner on a work project?

•	How likely would you be to ask Tyrone for help on a task or assignment if you were struggling?
We will analyze the data with a one-way ANOVA and a series of planned contrasts.

attributes.title: Psychometric properties of tools to measure the external validity of randomized controlled trials: a systematic review
attributes.description: This planned systematic review aims to identify tools to measure the external validity of RCTs and to further evaluate their psychometric properties.

q1.value: Psychometric properties of tools to measure the external validity of randomized controlled trials: a systematic review

q2.value: Andres Jung, Julia Balzer, Tobias Braun, Kerstin Luedtke

q3.value:
The overall quality of clinical trials is considered to be essential for the informative value and predictive power of systematic reviews/meta-analysis in medical research, as their results are used for treatment recommendations or development of clinical guidelines. Accordingly, evaluation of internal and external validity of clinical trials, such as randomized controlled trials (RCTs) is a key step for research implantation into clinical practice (Jüni, Altman & Egger, 2001). Internal validity considers how robust the study was conducted and reported. The focus of internal validity is the methodological quality as well as risk of bias of a study and allows a judgement as to how far the measured effects can be trusted (Cochrane Germany, 2016). External validity indicates whether study results can be transferred to another (patient) population, situation and/or circumstance (clinical context). Its evaluation depends on the specificity of the research question, the inclusion and exclusion criteria and the setting of the study (Cochrane Germany, 2016).
In health research, however, external validity is often neglected within the quality assessment process of clinical studies (Burchett et al., 2018; Dekkers et al., 2009). One possible explanation might be the lack of a gold standard for assessing external validity of clinical trials. Some reviews have examined frameworks and tools for assessing external validity of clinical trials in health research (Burchett et al., 2011; Cambon et al., 2012; Dyrvig et al., 2014; Nasser et al., 2011). New measurement instruments have been published since then. To our knowledge no comprehensive evaluation of the psychometric properties of measurement tools has been performed yet. In addition, consensus regarding terminology, criteria and evaluation of external validity in medical research is currently missing (Burchett et al., 2018; Burford et al., 2013; Dekkers et al., 2009). Accordingly, there is a need to scientifically evaluate the psychometric properties of tools to measure the external validity of clinical trials. This seems to be particularly important in the case of RCTs, as this research design is considered to be most suitable for investigating cause and effects mechanisms. Depending on the results of this planned review, the need to develop a new measurement tool for this purpose will be evaluated.
There is evidence that the accuracy of external validity assessment depends on the study design of the study considered for evaluation (Bornhöft et al., 2006; Gartlehner et al., 2006; Thorpe et al., 2009). Furthermore, it was shown, that for instance, the reliability of external validity evaluations with the same measurement tool differs between randomized and non-randomized trials (Downs & Out, 1998). In addition, due to differences in requested information for reporting guidelines, e.g. CONSORT, STROBE, respective items used for assessing the external validity can vary between different research designs. In line with the importance of RCTs in the medical field, this planned review will focus on measurement tools evaluating external validity of RCTs.

The aim of this review is to identify tools to measure the external validity of RCTs and to further evaluate their psychometric properties. Objectives:
1.	To identify published measurement tools to assess the external validity of RCTs.
2.	To analyze the characteristics and restrictions of these measurement tools in terms of terminology and criteria for assessing external validity.
3.	To evaluate psychometric properties of tools to assess the external validity of RCTs.
4.	To make recommendations for or against the use of tools to assess the external validity of RCTs in future systematic reviews.

q4.value: We hypothesize varying and incomplete psychometric evaluations and psychometric properties of the existing tools to measure the external validity of RCTs. Thus, we will establish a comprehensive list of the published measurement tools and summarize the findings on their psychometric properties.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: systematic review of psychometric properties

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
This systematic review will be carried out in accordance with the Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) Statement (Liberati et al., 2009) and the COSMIN methodology for systematic reviews of measurement instruments in health sciences (Mokkink et al., 2018a; Prinsen et al., 2018; Terwee et al., 2018). 


Literature search, data extraction and management
The eligibility criteria and search strategy will be elaborated in collaboration with a research librarian. A literature search will be carried out to identify published tools to assess the external validity of RCTs. Abstracts and full‐text screening will be performed independently by two researchers, in relation to a priori defined in- and exclusion criteria. 
(see Appendix 1: search strategy and inclusion criteria)

Next, a literature search will be carried out for studies evaluating psychometric properties of each prior included tool. Data extraction will be performed independently by two researchers (see Appendix 1).

As an intermediate step, we will perform a scoping review evaluating the characteristics as well as limitations of existing quality assessment tools that include adequate items to assess the external validity of clinical trials. The summary and report of the results for the scoping review will be carried out based on recommendations of Arksey & O’Malley (2005) and Colquhoun et al. (2014).


Risk of bias assessment
The risk of bias assessment will be carried out using the COSMIN tool (Mokkink et al., 2018b) to evaluate robustness of the applied methods and the quality of the psychometric properties of the included tools. The COSMIN checklist is a valid tool (Mokkink et al. 2010a; Mokkink et al. 2010b; Mokkink et al. 2017; Terwee et al., 2018) designed for systematic evaluation of methodological quality in studies assessing the psychometric properties of health measurement instruments (Mokkink et al., 2018b). Although this checklist was specifically developed for systematic reviews of patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs), it can also be used for reviews of non-PROMs (Prinsen et al., 2018). As mentioned in the COSMIN user manual, adaptations for some items in the COSMIN Risk of Bias checklist might be necessary, in relation to the construct being measured (Mokkink et al., 2018c, p. 9). Therefore, we will perform pilot tests of the assessment of psychometric properties of measurement tools assessing the quality (internal validity/methodological quality) of RCTs, to ensure feasibility and reliability during the planned evaluation of the included tools. After each testing, results and problems regarding the comprehensibility and feasibility of the instructions, items and response options will be discussed. If needed, adaptations and/or supplements will be done for the instruction of the evaluation with the COSMIN risk of bias checklist. Adaptations will be done until saturation has been reached. To ensure face validity, no items of the COSMIN risk of bias tool will be modified, but we consider to specify some items if appropriate. Pilot-tests will be performed before data extraction. After data extraction, all included psychometric studies will be systematically evaluated by two independent reviewers. In case of disagreement, a third reviewer will be available to discuss and achieve consensus.

q13.value: N/A. Depending on the quantity of published articles that meets the inclusion criteria.

question.value: N/A

Characteristics and limitations of tools: interpretability, feasibility and psychometric properties of included tools according to COSMIN methodology. Psychometric properties are: content validity, criterion validity, construct validity and reliability.

Qualitative synthesis will be performed predominantly according to COSMIN methodology. If several psychometric studies reveal quantitative data on internal consistency, reliability, measurement error, hypotheses testing and/or responsiveness of a measurement tool and the data is homogenous, the results will be pooled using generic inverse variance (random effects) methodology. We will calculate weighted means and 95% confidence intervals for each measurement property.

registration_responses.q1: Psychometric properties of tools to measure the external validity of randomized controlled trials: a systematic review
registration_responses.q2: Andres Jung, Julia Balzer, Tobias Braun, Kerstin Luedtke
registration_responses.q3:
The overall quality of clinical trials is considered to be essential for the informative value and predictive power of systematic reviews/meta-analysis in medical research, as their results are used for treatment recommendations or development of clinical guidelines. Accordingly, evaluation of internal and external validity of clinical trials, such as randomized controlled trials (RCTs) is a key step for research implantation into clinical practice (Jüni, Altman & Egger, 2001). Internal validity considers how robust the study was conducted and reported. The focus of internal validity is the methodological quality as well as risk of bias of a study and allows a judgement as to how far the measured effects can be trusted (Cochrane Germany, 2016). External validity indicates whether study results can be transferred to another (patient) population, situation and/or circumstance (clinical context). Its evaluation depends on the specificity of the research question, the inclusion and exclusion criteria and the setting of the study (Cochrane Germany, 2016).
In health research, however, external validity is often neglected within the quality assessment process of clinical studies (Burchett et al., 2018; Dekkers et al., 2009). One possible explanation might be the lack of a gold standard for assessing external validity of clinical trials. Some reviews have examined frameworks and tools for assessing external validity of clinical trials in health research (Burchett et al., 2011; Cambon et al., 2012; Dyrvig et al., 2014; Nasser et al., 2011). New measurement instruments have been published since then. To our knowledge no comprehensive evaluation of the psychometric properties of measurement tools has been performed yet. In addition, consensus regarding terminology, criteria and evaluation of external validity in medical research is currently missing (Burchett et al., 2018; Burford et al., 2013; Dekkers et al., 2009). Accordingly, there is a need to scientifically evaluate the psychometric properties of tools to measure the external validity of clinical trials. This seems to be particularly important in the case of RCTs, as this research design is considered to be most suitable for investigating cause and effects mechanisms. Depending on the results of this planned review, the need to develop a new measurement tool for this purpose will be evaluated.
There is evidence that the accuracy of external validity assessment depends on the study design of the study considered for evaluation (Bornhöft et al., 2006; Gartlehner et al., 2006; Thorpe et al., 2009). Furthermore, it was shown, that for instance, the reliability of external validity evaluations with the same measurement tool differs between randomized and non-randomized trials (Downs & Out, 1998). In addition, due to differences in requested information for reporting guidelines, e.g. CONSORT, STROBE, respective items used for assessing the external validity can vary between different research designs. In line with the importance of RCTs in the medical field, this planned review will focus on measurement tools evaluating external validity of RCTs.

The aim of this review is to identify tools to measure the external validity of RCTs and to further evaluate their psychometric properties. Objectives:
1.	To identify published measurement tools to assess the external validity of RCTs.
2.	To analyze the characteristics and restrictions of these measurement tools in terms of terminology and criteria for assessing external validity.
3.	To evaluate psychometric properties of tools to assess the external validity of RCTs.
4.	To make recommendations for or against the use of tools to assess the external validity of RCTs in future systematic reviews.
registration_responses.q4: We hypothesize varying and incomplete psychometric evaluations and psychometric properties of the existing tools to measure the external validity of RCTs. Thus, we will establish a comprehensive list of the published measurement tools and summarize the findings on their psychometric properties.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q8.question: systematic review of psychometric properties
registration_responses.q12.question:
This systematic review will be carried out in accordance with the Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) Statement (Liberati et al., 2009) and the COSMIN methodology for systematic reviews of measurement instruments in health sciences (Mokkink et al., 2018a; Prinsen et al., 2018; Terwee et al., 2018). 


Literature search, data extraction and management
The eligibility criteria and search strategy will be elaborated in collaboration with a research librarian. A literature search will be carried out to identify published tools to assess the external validity of RCTs. Abstracts and full‐text screening will be performed independently by two researchers, in relation to a priori defined in- and exclusion criteria. 
(see Appendix 1: search strategy and inclusion criteria)

Next, a literature search will be carried out for studies evaluating psychometric properties of each prior included tool. Data extraction will be performed independently by two researchers (see Appendix 1).

As an intermediate step, we will perform a scoping review evaluating the characteristics as well as limitations of existing quality assessment tools that include adequate items to assess the external validity of clinical trials. The summary and report of the results for the scoping review will be carried out based on recommendations of Arksey & O’Malley (2005) and Colquhoun et al. (2014).


Risk of bias assessment
The risk of bias assessment will be carried out using the COSMIN tool (Mokkink et al., 2018b) to evaluate robustness of the applied methods and the quality of the psychometric properties of the included tools. The COSMIN checklist is a valid tool (Mokkink et al. 2010a; Mokkink et al. 2010b; Mokkink et al. 2017; Terwee et al., 2018) designed for systematic evaluation of methodological quality in studies assessing the psychometric properties of health measurement instruments (Mokkink et al., 2018b). Although this checklist was specifically developed for systematic reviews of patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs), it can also be used for reviews of non-PROMs (Prinsen et al., 2018). As mentioned in the COSMIN user manual, adaptations for some items in the COSMIN Risk of Bias checklist might be necessary, in relation to the construct being measured (Mokkink et al., 2018c, p. 9). Therefore, we will perform pilot tests of the assessment of psychometric properties of measurement tools assessing the quality (internal validity/methodological quality) of RCTs, to ensure feasibility and reliability during the planned evaluation of the included tools. After each testing, results and problems regarding the comprehensibility and feasibility of the instructions, items and response options will be discussed. If needed, adaptations and/or supplements will be done for the instruction of the evaluation with the COSMIN risk of bias checklist. Adaptations will be done until saturation has been reached. To ensure face validity, no items of the COSMIN risk of bias tool will be modified, but we consider to specify some items if appropriate. Pilot-tests will be performed before data extraction. After data extraction, all included psychometric studies will be systematically evaluated by two independent reviewers. In case of disagreement, a third reviewer will be available to discuss and achieve consensus.
registration_responses.q16.question: N/A
registration_responses.q17.question: Characteristics and limitations of tools: interpretability, feasibility and psychometric properties of included tools according to COSMIN methodology. Psychometric properties are: content validity, criterion validity, construct validity and reliability.
registration_responses.q19.question: Qualitative synthesis will be performed predominantly according to COSMIN methodology. If several psychometric studies reveal quantitative data on internal consistency, reliability, measurement error, hypotheses testing and/or responsiveness of a measurement tool and the data is homogenous, the results will be pooled using generic inverse variance (random effects) methodology. We will calculate weighted means and 95% confidence intervals for each measurement property.

attributes.title: Consequences of the belief in a free will

q1.value: Consequences of the belief in a free will

q3.value: This study tries to link the belief in a free will with certain outcomes, in particular punishment and forgiveness. We will test some theoretical considerations of the German philosopher, Michael Schmidt-Salomon. He states that the belief in a free will does humanity no good and it is better to withdraw from that belief, which comes with various positive consequences for humanity.

q4.value:
H1: The less people believe in free will, the more they are motivated to be empathic.
H2: The less people believe in free will, the more they search for the causes of crime.
H3a: The less people believe in free will, the less strong is their desire to punish others in order to retaliate.
H3b: The relation between belief in free will and desire to punish others in order to retaliate is mediated by the motivation to be empathic.
H3c: The relation between belief in free will and desire to punish others in order to retaliate is mediated by the search for the causes of crime.
H4a: The less people believe in free will, the less they are willing to forgive others.
H4b: The relation between belief in free will and willingness to forgive others is mediated by the motivation to be empathic.
H4c: The relation between belief in free will and willingness to forgive others is mediated by the search for the causes of crime.
H5a: The more people have engaged with the issue of free will, the more pronounced is the assumed effect of the belief in free will on the motivation to be empathic.
H5b: The more people have engaged with the issue of free will, the more pronounced is the assumed effect of the belief in free will on the search for the causes of crime.
H5c: The more people have engaged with the issue of free will, the more pronounced is the assumed effect of the belief in free will on the desire to punish others in order to retaliate.
H5d: The more people have engaged with the issue of free will, the more pronounced is the assumed effect of the belief in free will on the willingness to forgive others.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study is a cross-sectional study, where all participants receive the same online questionnaire.

q9.value: The only randomization will be that the sequence of the scales for 'belief in free will' and 'belief in free act' will be randomized for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through display on social media, on websites for online surveys, through student bodies, through personal contacts, and professional associations. Participants won't receive expense allowances. Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 310 participants. We will attempt to recruit 350 participants assuming that some participants might not be included in the analyses.

q14.value: In order to determine the sample size for the analysis, a power analysis ("linear multiple regression: fixed model, R^2 deviation from zero") was conducted using G*Power 3.1 (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner & Lang, 2009). The analysis was based on the multiple linear regression model that will be used for this study. With a small to medium effect size of f^2=.05, an alpha of .05, a power level of .80, and a total of 8 predictors, the results of the power analysis showed that a minimum of 309 participants would be needed.

q15.value: The online questionnaire will be accessible for at least three weeks. If after three weeks, the number of participants is still below 350, access will be continued until 350 participants have completed it.

question.value:
The measured variables (predictors and outcomes) will be 'belief in free will', 'belief in free act', 'motivation to empathy', 'search for causes of crime', 'retributional punishment' and 'forgiveness to others'.

The constructs 'belief in free will' and 'belief in free act' will be measured with a newly developed questionnaire by Stanke (2014). We will use the revised version by Hetmann (2018). It consists of 13 items for 'belief in free will' and 10 items for 'belief in free act'. Participants answer the items on a 5-point scale. Before filling out the questionnaire, the participants will be given a text, which defines free will and free act and gives the reader an idea of the difference between the two concepts. After the text the participants have to answer two comprehension questions about it.

In addition, 'belief in free will' will be measured with the subscale "free will" of the FAD-Plus by Paulhus and Carey (2011). It consists of 7 items, which are answered on a 5-point scale.

The construct 'motivation to empathy' will be measured with the subscale "perspective taking" of the "Saarbrücker Persönlichkeitsfragebogen" by Paulus (2009). This scale is the German version of the "Interpersonal Reactivity Index " (IRI; Davis, 1980). This subscale consists of four items, which are answered on a 5-point-scale.

The construct 'search for causes of crime' will be measured with a newly developed 1-item-scale. Participants will be asked 'What do you think, which factors can have an influence, why persons commit crimes?'. They can choose out of 29 possible answers, where they can pick as much answers as they would like to. 

The construct 'retributional punishment' will be measured with the scale 'Retribution as Revenge and Retribution as Just Deserts' by Gerber and Jackson (2013). For the usage the scale was translated into German. The scale consists of 12 items, which are answered on a 7-point scale.

The construct 'forgiveness of others' will be measured with the scale "Skala der Bereitschaft zu verzeihen" (SBV) by Allemand, Sassin-Meng, Huber and Schmitt (2008). It consists of 8 fictional scenarios, where a perpetrator harms the participant. In 4 of the scenarios the perpetrator shows repentance, in the other 4 not. The participants are then asked, if they could forgive the perpetrator for this transgression completely. Answers are given on a 5-point scale.

The engagement with the issue of free will will be measured with a single item and answered on a 5-point scale.

Political orientation and religiousness will be included as covariates in the analyses.
Political orientation will be measured with a slider with the two poles 'left' and 'right'.
Religiousness will as well be measured with a slider with the two poles 'non-religious' and 'religious'.

To test hypotheses H1 and H5a we will compute a linear regression model with 8 predictors. The independent variable will be 'belief in free will'. The dependent variable will be 'motivation to empathy'. 'Engagement with the issue of free will' will be included as a moderator. The covariates will be 'political orientation', 'religiousness', 'age', 'gender' and 'level of education'.

To test hypotheses H2 and H5b we will compute a linear regression model with 8 predictors. The independent variable will be 'belief in free will'. The dependent variable will be 'search for causes of crime'. 'Engagement with the issue of free will' will be included as a moderator. The covariates will be 'political orientation', 'religiousness', 'age', 'gender' and 'level of education'.

To test hypotheses H3a and H5c we will compute a linear regression model with 8 predictors. The independent variable will be 'belief in free will'. The dependent variable will be 'retributional punishment'. 'Engagement with the issue of free will' will be included as a moderator. The covariates will be 'political orientation', 'religiousness', 'age', 'gender' and 'level of education'.

To test hypotheses H4a and H5d we will compute a linear regression model with 8 predictors. The independent variable will be 'belief in free will'. The dependent variable will be 'forgiveness to others'. 'Engagement with the issue of free will' will be included as a moderator. The covariates will be 'political orientation', 'religiousness', 'age', 'gender' and 'level of education'.

To test hypotheses H3b, H3c, H4b and H4c I will do two individual mediation analyses with bootstrapping method. The independent variable will be 'belief in free will' for each model. The mediators will be 'motivation to empathy' and 'search for causes of crime' for each model. The dependent variables for the two individual models will be 'retributional punishment' and 'forgiveness to others'. The covariates for both analyses will be 'political orientation', 'religiousness', 'age', 'gender' and 'level of education'.

q20.value:
We will transform variables whose skewness exceeds a value of 2 with the transformations suggested by Tabachnik and Fidell (2007). We will use the transformed variable with the lowest skewness for further analyses. 
We define univariate outliers as scores which lay outside M +/- 4 SD. We will transform these outliers in scores of M +/- 4 SD to reduce their impact on the analyses.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the effects will be significantly different from zero.

q22.value:
The participants will indicate the degree of disturbance they felt while filling out the questionnaire on a scale between 1 (“very low”) - 5 (“very high”). Those who indicate a value equal or more than 4 will be excluded from the analysis. 
Participants will be asked if they read the questions and items properly and answered them honestly. If they don't answer with 'yes' they will be excluded from the analysis.
Participants will be asked if they allow their data to be used for scientific purposes. If they don't answer with 'yes' they will be excluded from the analysis.
Participants will be excluded if they need less than 5 minutes to participate in the study.
Participants will be excluded if they answer the comprehension questions after the text about free will and free act wrongly two times.

q23.value: We will calculate scale scores for participants who answered at least half of the items of the respective scale.

q24.value: We're planning on doing an exploratory analysis regarding hypotheses H1 to H4 concerning the belief in free will. Here we will compare the correlations of two different scales measuring the belief in a free will with the postulated outcomes with each other and see if one of them predicts the postulated outcomes better than the other.

q25.value:

Participants will be asked if they allow their data to be used for scientific purposes. If they don't answer with 'yes' they will be excluded from the analysis.
Participants will be excluded if they need less than 5 minutes to participate in the study.
Participants will be excluded if they answer the comprehension questions after the text about free will and free act wrongly two times.
registration_responses.q23: We will calculate scale scores for participants who answered at least half of the items of the respective scale.
registration_responses.q24: We're planning on doing an exploratory analysis regarding hypotheses H1 to H4 concerning the belief in free will. Here we will compare the correlations of two different scales measuring the belief in a free will with the postulated outcomes with each other and see if one of them predicts the postulated outcomes better than the other.

registration_responses.q8.question: The study is a cross-sectional study, where all participants receive the same online questionnaire.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited through display on social media, on websites for online surveys, through student bodies, through personal contacts, and professional associations. Participants won't receive expense allowances. Participants must be at least 18 years old.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The measured variables (predictors and outcomes) will be 'belief in free will', 'belief in free act', 'motivation to empathy', 'search for causes of crime', 'retributional punishment' and 'forgiveness to others'.

The constructs 'belief in free will' and 'belief in free act' will be measured with a newly developed questionnaire by Stanke (2014). We will use the revised version by Hetmann (2018). It consists of 13 items for 'belief in free will' and 10 items for 'belief in free act'. Participants answer the items on a 5-point scale. Before filling out the questionnaire, the participants will be given a text, which defines free will and free act and gives the reader an idea of the difference between the two concepts. After the text the participants have to answer two comprehension questions about it.

In addition, 'belief in free will' will be measured with the subscale "free will" of the FAD-Plus by Paulhus and Carey (2011). It consists of 7 items, which are answered on a 5-point scale.

The construct 'motivation to empathy' will be measured with the subscale "perspective taking" of the "Saarbrücker Persönlichkeitsfragebogen" by Paulus (2009). This scale is the German version of the "Interpersonal Reactivity Index " (IRI; Davis, 1980). This subscale consists of four items, which are answered on a 5-point-scale.

The construct 'search for causes of crime' will be measured with a newly developed 1-item-scale. Participants will be asked 'What do you think, which factors can have an influence, why persons commit crimes?'. They can choose out of 29 possible answers, where they can pick as much answers as they would like to. 

The construct 'retributional punishment' will be measured with the scale 'Retribution as Revenge and Retribution as Just Deserts' by Gerber and Jackson (2013). For the usage the scale was translated into German. The scale consists of 12 items, which are answered on a 7-point scale.

The construct 'forgiveness of others' will be measured with the scale "Skala der Bereitschaft zu verzeihen" (SBV) by Allemand, Sassin-Meng, Huber and Schmitt (2008). It consists of 8 fictional scenarios, where a perpetrator harms the participant. In 4 of the scenarios the perpetrator shows repentance, in the other 4 not. The participants are then asked, if they could forgive the perpetrator for this transgression completely. Answers are given on a 5-point scale.

The engagement with the issue of free will will be measured with a single item and answered on a 5-point scale.

Political orientation and religiousness will be included as covariates in the analyses.
Political orientation will be measured with a slider with the two poles 'left' and 'right'.
Religiousness will as well be measured with a slider with the two poles 'non-religious' and 'religious'.
registration_responses.q19.question:
To test hypotheses H1 and H5a we will compute a linear regression model with 8 predictors. The independent variable will be 'belief in free will'. The dependent variable will be 'motivation to empathy'. 'Engagement with the issue of free will' will be included as a moderator. The covariates will be 'political orientation', 'religiousness', 'age', 'gender' and 'level of education'.

To test hypotheses H2 and H5b we will compute a linear regression model with 8 predictors. The independent variable will be 'belief in free will'. The dependent variable will be 'search for causes of crime'. 'Engagement with the issue of free will' will be included as a moderator. The covariates will be 'political orientation', 'religiousness', 'age', 'gender' and 'level of education'.

To test hypotheses H3a and H5c we will compute a linear regression model with 8 predictors. The independent variable will be 'belief in free will'. The dependent variable will be 'retributional punishment'. 'Engagement with the issue of free will' will be included as a moderator. The covariates will be 'political orientation', 'religiousness', 'age', 'gender' and 'level of education'.

To test hypotheses H4a and H5d we will compute a linear regression model with 8 predictors. The independent variable will be 'belief in free will'. The dependent variable will be 'forgiveness to others'. 'Engagement with the issue of free will' will be included as a moderator. The covariates will be 'political orientation', 'religiousness', 'age', 'gender' and 'level of education'.

To test hypotheses H3b, H3c, H4b and H4c I will do two individual mediation analyses with bootstrapping method. The independent variable will be 'belief in free will' for each model. The mediators will be 'motivation to empathy' and 'search for causes of crime' for each model. The dependent variables for the two individual models will be 'retributional punishment' and 'forgiveness to others'. The covariates for both analyses will be 'political orientation', 'religiousness', 'age', 'gender' and 'level of education'.

attributes.title: the effect of analytic and intuitive cognitive style on gullibility (Study 2)

q1.value: The effect of analytic and intuitive cognitive style on gullibility (Study 2)

q3.value:
In Study 1 (https://osf.io/u5pzc/?view_only=e79a5f42cf8442aba88fe83d1cc92cc7) we examined the effect of analytical thinking on gullibility and attribution of paranormal causation to the uncanny event. We tried to replicate the main effect of analytic cognitive style on the likelihood to accept supernatural causation vs. effect of source of information (how the profile is “produced”). Compared to original study (Bouvet & Bonnefon, 2015) we extend the research by experimental design where we manipulated the analytic cognitive style as well as the source of the profile (psychology test vs. astrology profile), and by controlling prior paranormal beliefs, anomalous experiences, paranormal attribution to these experiences, and emotion (depression, anxiety) as possible mediators of the relationship between analytic cognitive style and gullibility. 
We found out that analytic cognitive style together with the knowledge of the source of information (astrology vs. psychology) and prior paranormal beliefs (PBS) affected gullibility in case of uncanny event: people in psychology condition (psychological test as source of information) perceived the fake profile as more accurate (were more gullible), but source of information was only marginally significant predictor of gullibility; stronger predictors of gullibility were the analytic cognitive style and prior paranormal beliefs (PBS). 
The main aim of the planned study is to support findings from Study 1: we will try to replicate the main effect of analytic cognitive style and the source of information (how the profile is “produced”) on the likelihood to accept supernatural causation by expanded manipulation of the analytic cognitive style. Because in the Study 1 manipulation of analytic thinking through simple instruction did not work, in Study 2 we will modify the manipulation in two ways. First, we will manipulate cognitive style in two directions; we will induce analytic as well as intuitive cognitive style. Second, we will extend the manipulation form: we will use the verbal priming – instruction as well as task inducing analytic or intuitive cognitive style.
Our main research questions are:
1)	Does analytic cognitive style prevent gullibility and susceptibility to the paranormal explanation of uncanny event (in comparison to intuitive cognitive style and control condition)?
2)	Or possibly, is it the knowledge of the source of information that affects gullibility and susceptibility to the paranormal explanation of uncanny events?
3)	Do prior paranormal beliefs, proneness to anomalous experience and explanation, and negative emotionality predict gullibility and susceptibility to paranormal explanations of an uncanny event over and above analytical thinking?

q4.value:
We plan a 3x2 experiment with between-participant design. As in Study 1, participants will be told that the goal is to study various methods of personality mapping and some of them will rate personality profile created on the basis of the birth date (astrology condition) and some of them will rate personality profile created by the set of psychological tests (psychology condition). Moreover, we will manipulate their engagement of analytical and intuitive thinking by encouraging them to think things through (analytic condition) or to answer according to their gut feeling (intuitive condition), or no specific instruction (control condition). All participants will receive the same Barnum profile (Bouvet & Bonnefon, 2015; Forer, 1949) and will be asked to rate it for accuracy and uncanniness and this will comprise the main dependent variable. 
We verify three possible effects: 
(H1) Analytic cognitive style prevents the gullibility. Specifically, if participants in analytic condition will perceive their profile as less accurate and will attribute coincidence to profile accuracy & if participants in intuitive condition will perceive their profile as more accurate and will attribute uncanniness to profile accuracy —regardless of the source of profile (astrology vs. psychology)—in comparison to control group, it will be evidence of main effect of analytic cognitive style.
(H2) The Source of the profile (astrology vs. psychology) affects gullibility. Specifically, if participants in astrology condition will perceive their profile as less accurate and will attribute coincidence to profile accuracy—regardless of being in analytical thinking condition or control group—in comparison to the psychological condition, it will be evidence of the main effect of source of information (cue).
(H3) Both the analytic cognitive style and source of information (cue) affect the gullibility. Specifically, if participants in analytical thinking condition will perceive their profile as less accurate only when it would be produced by astrology, it will be evidence of the interaction effect of analytical thinking and source of information (cue).
Moreover, we expect that:
(H4) Prior paranormal beliefs will predict gullibility over and above the effects of manipulation (analytic thinking and source of information).
(H5) Proneness to anomalous explanation will predict gullibility over and above the effects of manipulation (analytic thinking and source of information).
(H6) Negative emotionality (depression, anxiety) will predict gullibility over and above the effects of manipulation (analytic thinking and source of information).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We plan an experiment with between-participant design (Figure 1): 3 (analytic and intuitive cognitive style manipulation vs. no manipulation) x 2 (astrological condition vs. psychological condition). After reading and signing the informed consent form, the participants will be told that we study the effectiveness of various methods of mapping personality. 
First, we will measure paranormal beliefs (PBS), anomalous experiences, paranormal attribution to anomalous experiences (SAE), and emotion (depression, anxiety from BFI2). These blocks will be resented in random order. Next, participants will be randomly divided into control and experimental groups (sex, age, and education balanced). In the experimental group, we will manipulate analytic and intuitive cognitive style—participants will be instructed to think/reflect their answers in following tasks or to answer fast and by gut feelings; participants in the control group will continue without instruction. Then, all of them will solve CRT and as control of cognitive style manipulation—participants will rate whether they really think their answers in CRT. The higher score in self-rating questions in the analytic experimental group will be the evidence that manipulation worked.
Finally, in each group half of participants will rate profiles with astrological origin (astrological condition)—created by their birth date—and half of them will rate profiles with psychological origin (psychological condition)—created by their scores in a psychological test. In fact, both profiles will be fake (Barnum profile); participants will rate the accuracy of the presented profile and state what they attribute to the profile (coincidence versus astrology/psychology test). We will finally have four groups: experimental with astrology profile, experimental with psychological profile, control with astrology profile, and control with a psychological profile.

q9.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to experimental and control groups, as well as to astrology and psychology condition. In all six final groups the gender and age will be balanced (randomization and filters available in Qualtrics).
The order of BFI2, PBS, and SAE, as well as items in the blocks (CRT, PBS, and SAE), will be randomized to avoid the order effect. The order of items in BFI2 is set—one item from each dimension, the order is repeated.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Data will be collected by an external agency (to be chosen in a tender) through an online survey hosted on Qualtrics; the agency complies with international code ESOMAR. Participants will be selected to the sample in accordance with predetermined criteria (age 18+, balanced men and women, balanced education, a maximum of 10% university students). Participants will be rewarded with points (within the remuneration system of external agency) which can be exchanged for various products.
Participants will be told that we study various methods of personality mapping and some of them will rate personality profile created by the birth date and some of them will rate personality profile created by the set of psychological tests. In fact, all of them will rate fake Barnum profile. All participants will be duly debriefed after completing the study.
Collected data will be only those relevant to the research purpose and data will be anonymized so they cannot be traced nor an individual’s identity inferred via deductive disclosure; the anonymized data will be shared through the OSF. The study will be carried out in accordance with ethical principles introduced by the American Psychological Association.
To prevent the accidental filling of tasks we will include two control questions (attention checks) such as “If you read this sentence, press 2”. Participants who will fail to select the correct answer will be excluded from the data set. At the same time, an external agency will oversample in order to meet—after data control—the requested sample size and quality of data. Data will be checked for unfinished questionnaires, extreme values, time taken to fill in the questionnaire, and peculiar patterns of answers indicating mindless responding (checking all a´s, etc.).

q13.value: We plan to analyze data from around 420 participants. Both, in each condition (analytic and intuitive thinking group and control group) there will be 140 participants (210 in astrological and 210 in psychological condition).

q14.value: To determine sample size, we have applied a priori power analysis for a two-way ANOVA. The analysis was conducted using an alpha of 0.05, a power of 0.95, an effect size of 0.25, and the number of groups 6. Based on the aforementioned assumptions, the desired sample is 400+10%.

q15.value: External agency will terminate data collection after reaching the number of 440.

question.value:
Cognitive style manipulation. Participants will be divided into three groups – two experimental (analytic and intuitive thinking condition) and control group. In experimental – analytical group, we will prompt participants to use analytic cognitive style first by instruction “In many life situations, it is important that we think carefully about things. Now, we will test this ability, so when answering the following tasks, please think thoroughly about your response.” and second by analytic task (solving verbal task). In experimental – intuitive group, we will prompt participants to use intuitive cognitive style first by instruction “In many life situations, it is better to decide fast, according our gut feelings. Now, we will test this ability, so when answering the following tasks, please answer quickly, base your answer on your gut feelings.” and also by intuitive task (solving verbal task). In control group there will be no instruction. 
Participants will then solve six tasks from Cognitive Reflection Test (Frederick, 2005) – three mathematical and three verbal tasks. Number of correct responses will serve as manipulation check, as we expect that analytic thinking prompt should increase participants´ awareness about the tricky nature of this test. As a second manipulation check, we will ask participant to rate how thoroughly they thought about their answers on 7-point scale (the higher score in self-rating question will be the evidence that manipulation worked).
Source of information manipulation. After first manipulation (analytic cognitive style vs. control group), participants will be divided into two conditions – astrological and psychological. In astrological condition, participants will be asked to provide their date of birth so that their astrological profile can be created. To enhance the esoteric nature of this condition, mandala will appear on the screen for few seconds asking participants to wait while their unique astrological profile is being calculated. In psychology conditions participants will be told that psychological profile will be created based on their score in previous set of psychological tests. After this manipulation, all participants will receive the same Barnum´s profile consisting of 12 vague sentences (Bouvet & Bonnefon, 2015; Forer, 1949).

Dependant variables:
Gullibility. Gullibility will be measured by three questions related to perceived accuracy of the profile and one question related to perceived accuracy of used method (astrology vs. psychology). Participants will be asked to rate on 7-point scale (1=not at all; 7=completely yes) how precise, unique, revealing the features and personality the fake profiles are. Mean rating of perceived accuracy of the profiles is gullibility (higher score in indicates higher acceptance of vague and general Barnum profile). [Gullibility = sum of P1, P2, P3, P7]. 
Paranormal explanation. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with three explanations of what just happened on 7-point scale (1=strongly disagree; 7 = strongly agree): “profile is the result of coincidence, luck,” “these statements may characterize many people,” and “the profile is the result of something inexplicable, mystery.” [Explanation = sum of P4, P5, P6]. Randomness score will be recoded, so the higher score will reflect higher belief that the profile is perceived as unique and not random.
Predictors:
Prior paranormal beliefs will be measured by Paranormal Belief Scale (PBS; Tobacyk, 2004), which consists of 26 items measuring various paranormal beliefs, such as witchcraft, precognition or superstition. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with the items on 7-point scale (1=strongly disagree; 7 = strongly agree). One item is reverse scored. Higher score indicates higher paranormal belief [PBS]. 
Proneness to anomalous experience and explanation. We will use the SAE (The Survey of Anomalous Experience; Irwin, Dagnall, & Drinkwater, 2013), which comprises of 20 items addressing various anomalous experiences (e.g. I have become aware of a scent in a room, yet there was nothing there that could have that smell). First, participants have to indicate whether each of anomalous experience has already happened to them, then they further clarify their position by stating whether they attributed this experience to paranormal process (e.g. Yes, and it must have been an instance of an apparition or ESP) or to a specified non-paranormal process (e.g. Yes, but it was probably just an illusion or psychological anomaly). Based on the answers, two scores were computed: proneness to anomalous experiences [anomalous_experience] is the percentage of the “yes” answers and proneness to anomalous explanation [anomalous_explanation] is the percentage of supernatural attributions of the anomalous experiences. 
Negative emotionality. We will use Big Five Inventory 2 – Slovak version (BFI2; Soto & John, 2017, Slovak translation by Halama, Kohút, 2019). Participants will rate on 5-point scale (0=I disagree at all; 4=I totally agree) how 60 statements describe them. We will compute mean score from 4 items measuring depression [depression] and from 4 items measuring anxiety [anxiety] (higher score indicates higher tendency in both cases).
Socio-demographic variables:
Age
Gender

For dependent variables (gullibility and paranormal explanation), as well as prior paranormal beliefs (PBS) we will use mean score for the sake of better clarity, as they use the same 7-point scale but contain different number of items.
Proneness to anomalous experience and proneness to anomalous explanation will be calculated as percentages expressed as decimals.

Our analysis will include descriptive statistics and testing size, direction and confidence intervals of the measured effects. The profile rating, PBS, SAE, and BFI2 will be tested for their reliability and their factor structure. Only sufficiently reliable measures will be used in further analyses. To increase reliability of individual measures, excluding problematic or not working items may be necessary. 
After establishing sufficient reliability of our measures, we will check for normal distribution of the measured variables.

First, we will control whether analytic cognitive thinking manipulation worked. We will compare experimental and control groups in their score of self-rating of deliberate thinking engagement (one-way ANOVA). If the score in analytic experimental group will be significantly higher than in control group and intuitive experimental group, then we can conclude that the manipulation worked and we will conduct two-way ANOVA to verify hypotheses. If, on the other hand, there will be no differences among groups in score of self-rating of deliberate thinking engagement, then our manipulation did not work. In such case we will use the sum of CRT (participants´ level of analytical thinking) as predictor of gullibility in hierarchical regression analysis (similarly as Bouvet & Bonnefon, 2015) with source of information entered in the first step as dummy variable.
ANOVA will be used for verification of three possible effects specified in H1-H3.
To verify H4 – H6 we will use hierarchical linear regression with analytical thinking (CRT) entered in the first step, source of information in the second step (dummy variable, psycho=0, astro=1), prior paranormal beliefs (PBS), proneness to anomalous explanation (PAE) and negative emotionality (depression, anxiety) entered in the third step.

q20.value: We will recode score of uncanniness that a higher score indicates higher paranormal explanation similar to other scores that make up the index of gullibility.

q21.value: We will use conventional criteria of p < .005 for inferring statistical significance. We expect Cronbach´s alpha to be at least .7 to consider measure as satisfactorily reliable. We will use one-tail tests for each of our analyses. For multiple comparisons we will use Bonferoni correction

q22.value: Participants who will fail to select correct answer in control check questions will be excluded from data set, as well as those who will not finish questionnaires, those with extreme values, with extremely short time required to finish the questionnaire, or suspiciously filled grid questions.

q23.value: We will ask participants to answer all questions. In case of “don’t want to answer” or missing answer we will replace the answer with the mean value in the questionnaire. If any participant has more than 10% of incomplete items, they will be excluded from analyses.
