In fact, both profiles will be fake (Barnum profile); participants will rate the accuracy of the presented profile and state what they attribute to the profile (coincidence versus astrology/psychology test). We will finally have four groups: experimental with astrology profile, experimental with psychological profile, control with astrology profile, and control with a psychological profile.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Data will be collected by an external agency (to be chosen in a tender) through an online survey hosted on Qualtrics; the agency complies with international code ESOMAR. Participants will be selected to the sample in accordance with predetermined criteria (age 18+, balanced men and women, balanced education, a maximum of 10% university students). Participants will be rewarded with points (within the remuneration system of external agency) which can be exchanged for various products.
Participants will be told that we study various methods of personality mapping and some of them will rate personality profile created by the birth date and some of them will rate personality profile created by the set of psychological tests. In fact, all of them will rate fake Barnum profile. All participants will be duly debriefed after completing the study.
Collected data will be only those relevant to the research purpose and data will be anonymized so they cannot be traced nor an individual’s identity inferred via deductive disclosure; the anonymized data will be shared through the OSF. The study will be carried out in accordance with ethical principles introduced by the American Psychological Association.
To prevent the accidental filling of tasks we will include two control questions (attention checks) such as “If you read this sentence, press 2”. Participants who will fail to select the correct answer will be excluded from the data set. At the same time, an external agency will oversample in order to meet—after data control—the requested sample size and quality of data. Data will be checked for unfinished questionnaires, extreme values, time taken to fill in the questionnaire, and peculiar patterns of answers indicating mindless responding (checking all a´s, etc.).
registration_responses.q16.question:
Cognitive style manipulation. Participants will be divided into three groups – two experimental (analytic and intuitive thinking condition) and control group. In experimental – analytical group, we will prompt participants to use analytic cognitive style first by instruction “In many life situations, it is important that we think carefully about things. Now, we will test this ability, so when answering the following tasks, please think thoroughly about your response.” and second by analytic task (solving verbal task). In experimental – intuitive group, we will prompt participants to use intuitive cognitive style first by instruction “In many life situations, it is better to decide fast, according our gut feelings. Now, we will test this ability, so when answering the following tasks, please answer quickly, base your answer on your gut feelings.” and also by intuitive task (solving verbal task). In control group there will be no instruction. 
Participants will then solve six tasks from Cognitive Reflection Test (Frederick, 2005) – three mathematical and three verbal tasks. Number of correct responses will serve as manipulation check, as we expect that analytic thinking prompt should increase participants´ awareness about the tricky nature of this test. As a second manipulation check, we will ask participant to rate how thoroughly they thought about their answers on 7-point scale (the higher score in self-rating question will be the evidence that manipulation worked).
Source of information manipulation. After first manipulation (analytic cognitive style vs. control group), participants will be divided into two conditions – astrological and psychological. In astrological condition, participants will be asked to provide their date of birth so that their astrological profile can be created. To enhance the esoteric nature of this condition, mandala will appear on the screen for few seconds asking participants to wait while their unique astrological profile is being calculated. In psychology conditions participants will be told that psychological profile will be created based on their score in previous set of psychological tests. After this manipulation, all participants will receive the same Barnum´s profile consisting of 12 vague sentences (Bouvet & Bonnefon, 2015; Forer, 1949).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Dependant variables:
Gullibility. Gullibility will be measured by three questions related to perceived accuracy of the profile and one question related to perceived accuracy of used method (astrology vs. psychology). Participants will be asked to rate on 7-point scale (1=not at all; 7=completely yes) how precise, unique, revealing the features and personality the fake profiles are. Mean rating of perceived accuracy of the profiles is gullibility (higher score in indicates higher acceptance of vague and general Barnum profile). [Gullibility = sum of P1, P2, P3, P7]. 
Paranormal explanation. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with three explanations of what just happened on 7-point scale (1=strongly disagree; 7 = strongly agree): “profile is the result of coincidence, luck,” “these statements may characterize many people,” and “the profile is the result of something inexplicable, mystery.” [Explanation = sum of P4, P5, P6]. Randomness score will be recoded, so the higher score will reflect higher belief that the profile is perceived as unique and not random.
Predictors:
Prior paranormal beliefs will be measured by Paranormal Belief Scale (PBS; Tobacyk, 2004), which consists of 26 items measuring various paranormal beliefs, such as witchcraft, precognition or superstition. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with the items on 7-point scale (1=strongly disagree; 7 = strongly agree). One item is reverse scored. Higher score indicates higher paranormal belief [PBS]. 
Proneness to anomalous experience and explanation. We will use the SAE (The Survey of Anomalous Experience; Irwin, Dagnall, & Drinkwater, 2013), which comprises of 20 items addressing various anomalous experiences (e.g. I have become aware of a scent in a room, yet there was nothing there that could have that smell). First, participants have to indicate whether each of anomalous experience has already happened to them, then they further clarify their position by stating whether they attributed this experience to paranormal process (e.g. Yes, and it must have been an instance of an apparition or ESP) or to a specified non-paranormal process (e.g. Yes, but it was probably just an illusion or psychological anomaly). Based on the answers, two scores were computed: proneness to anomalous experiences [anomalous_experience] is the percentage of the “yes” answers and proneness to anomalous explanation [anomalous_explanation] is the percentage of supernatural attributions of the anomalous experiences. 
Negative emotionality. We will use Big Five Inventory 2 – Slovak version (BFI2; Soto & John, 2017, Slovak translation by Halama, Kohút, 2019). Participants will rate on 5-point scale (0=I disagree at all; 4=I totally agree) how 60 statements describe them. We will compute mean score from 4 items measuring depression [depression] and from 4 items measuring anxiety [anxiety] (higher score indicates higher tendency in both cases).
Socio-demographic variables:
Age
Gender
registration_responses.q18.question:
For dependent variables (gullibility and paranormal explanation), as well as prior paranormal beliefs (PBS) we will use mean score for the sake of better clarity, as they use the same 7-point scale but contain different number of items.
Proneness to anomalous experience and proneness to anomalous explanation will be calculated as percentages expressed as decimals.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Our analysis will include descriptive statistics and testing size, direction and confidence intervals of the measured effects. The profile rating, PBS, SAE, and BFI2 will be tested for their reliability and their factor structure. Only sufficiently reliable measures will be used in further analyses. To increase reliability of individual measures, excluding problematic or not working items may be necessary. 
After establishing sufficient reliability of our measures, we will check for normal distribution of the measured variables.

First, we will control whether analytic cognitive thinking manipulation worked. We will compare experimental and control groups in their score of self-rating of deliberate thinking engagement (one-way ANOVA). If the score in analytic experimental group will be significantly higher than in control group and intuitive experimental group, then we can conclude that the manipulation worked and we will conduct two-way ANOVA to verify hypotheses. If, on the other hand, there will be no differences among groups in score of self-rating of deliberate thinking engagement, then our manipulation did not work. In such case we will use the sum of CRT (participants´ level of analytical thinking) as predictor of gullibility in hierarchical regression analysis (similarly as Bouvet & Bonnefon, 2015) with source of information entered in the first step as dummy variable.
ANOVA will be used for verification of three possible effects specified in H1-H3.
To verify H4 – H6 we will use hierarchical linear regression with analytical thinking (CRT) entered in the first step, source of information in the second step (dummy variable, psycho=0, astro=1), prior paranormal beliefs (PBS), proneness to anomalous explanation (PAE) and negative emotionality (depression, anxiety) entered in the third step.

attributes.title: Consequences of the belief in a free will

attributes.title: The role of sleep in memory generalisation

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: The role of sleep in memory generalisation

other.value: In addition to testing our hypotheses on PC1, we will also test the effect of sleep on other principal components derived in the singular value decomposition. As noted, these are expected to reflect whether the spatial clustering of test trials response is specific to; a) the clustered condition (i.e. OC & NC but not OU & NU), and b) the 'new clustered' condition (i.e. NC but not OC, OU, or NU).

sample.value: Our maximum sample size will be 64 participants: 32 in the 'sleep' condition, 32 in the 'wake' condition. This was based on a minimum interesting effect size of d = 0.35. However, Bayesian tests of each hypothesis will be continually carried out during data-collection to assess the need for further recruitment. As such, data collection may terminate early if we obtain over 3 times more evidence in favour of the null or alternative for each a priori hypotheses.

analyses.value:
To compute our dependent variables, we will first generate probability density functions characterising the spatial distribution of each participant's responses. This will be done separately for the 4 different trial types (OU, OC, NU & NC). All responses will be made by selecting a spatial location on the perimeter of a circle. As such, we will estimate the probability density of responses using a kernel density estimation procedure with a circular smoothing kernel (the von Mises distribution, kappa = 2). Given these probability density functions, we will then compute the Kullback–Leibler divergence (Dkl scores) between responses in each condition and the spatial pattern underlying 'clustered' words at study (a Mises distribution, kappa = 2). Dkl scores vary between zero and positive infinity with low values indicating a close correspondence between responses and the clustered pattern.

Based on pilot data, we expect there to be distinct latent factors that will differentially correlate with Dkl scores in each condition. Most of the variance in Dkl scores should be attributable to a single factor describing the tendency of each participant to produce spatially clustered responses, regardless of trial type. A second factor should account how specific this response clustering is to the clustered trails in particular. A final factor may describe whether participants exhibit relatively more or less clustering in the 'new clustered' condition specifically. This is because responses in the NC condition cannot be made on the basis of the retrieval of a directly learnt word-location association and, as such, maybe more or less influenced by our clustering manipulation. We use a singular value decomposition to identify and extract all of these factors from the Dkl scores in each condition, across all participants. The main factor of interest will be the first principal component (PC1 scores); a factor describing the tendency of each participant to produce spatially clustered responses.

Hypothesis 1 will be tested with an independent samples t-test assessing the null hypothesis that PC1 scores from participants in the wake condition are sampled from the same population as PC1 scores from participants in the sleep condition.

Hypotheses 2a-2c involve testing the correlation between PC1 scores in the sleep group and predictor variables derived from the polysomnography (PSG) recordings; H2a) duration of Stage 3 sleep, H2b) slow oscillation activity, and H2c) sleep spindle density. Each hypothesis will be tested by computing the Pearson correlation coefficient between PC1 scores and each predictor of interest using independent bivariate correlations.

outliers.value: Participants data will be excluded from a statistical model if they produce residuals more than 2.5 standard deviations away from model-predicted values. If such exclusions are required, the singular value decomposition that generates our outcome of interest will re-run excluding the outlying participant.

dependent.value: The main dependent variable will measure the degree to which participants' responses adhere to the spatial pattern of locations seen during the study phase. This will be taken as the first principal component (PC1) from a singular value decomposition of Kullback–Leibler divergence statistics (see Analyses section below).

conditions.value:
Participants will be assigned to either a 'sleep' or a 'wake' condition. Those in the 'sleep' condition will sit the study phase in the evening (before bed), and the test phase the following morning. Overnight, these participants will sleep in a sleep laboratory where polysomnography recordings will be taken. Participants in the 'wake' condition will sit the study phase one morning, and the test phase later that evening. They will be free to go about their normal daily activities between the study and test phases.  In both conditions, the study and test phases will be separated by approximately 10.5 hours.

During the test phase, all participants will be presented with 4 different trial types; 1)  'old unclustered' [OU], 2) 'old clustered' [OC], 3) 'new unclustered' [NU], and 4) 'new clustered' [NC]. Here, 'clustered' test trials will cue the retrieval of semantically-related words (e.g. human-made objects) that have been associated with similar locations at study. 'Unclustered' test trials will belong to a distinct semantic category (e.g. natural objects) but, in contrast to the clustered words, will have been associated with entirely random locations during the study phase. 'Old' test trials will cue the retrieval of specific word-location associations that have been learnt during the study phase. In contrast, 'new' test trials will cue novel words that were not presented during the study phase but are semantically related to the studied word list.

As such, the experiment will include 2 within-subjects factors (factor 1: clustered vs unclustered words; factor 2: old vs new words). If participants have learnt that some words are associated with similar spatial locations, responses during the test phase may conform to this spatial pattern. Furthermore, if participants have learnt that the spatial cluster is specific to words in the clustered condition, their responses to clustered test trials may reflect this pattern more strongly than their responses to unclustered test trials. Finally, if spatially clustered responses are mediated by the semantic content of words rather than memories for specific word-location associations per se, the spatial clustering of responses should extend to 'new' as well as 'old' test trials.

hypothesis.value:
Hypothesis 1) Does sleep promote the extraction of generalised patterns across a set of similar items in human memory?... Participants will first learn a set of word-location associations (study phase). Following a retention interval (~10.5 hours), participants will be asked to recall the locations associated with each word (test phase; see https://psyarxiv.com/e8w7b/). A subset of the locations will conform to an underlying spatial pattern such that semantically related words will be associated with similar locations. We predict that all location estimates provided during the test phase will be more closely ahead to the underlying spatial pattern if participants have slept in the retention interval (relative to a 'wake' condition).

Hypothesis 2) Do memory consolidation processes during non-rapid eye movement (NREM) stage 3 sleep (N3) promote the extraction of generalised patterns?... We predict that the duration of N3 will correlate with how closely participants' location responses adhere to the underlying spatial pattern (hypothesis: H2a*). We also predict that EEG activity in the slow oscillation frequency range (1-4 Hz, hypothesis: H2b) and sleep spindle density (11-16 Hz, hypothesis: H2c) will show a similar correlation.

*Note: This prediction has been partially informed by peaking at a subset of the final data from 13 participants.

attributes.title: Dynamic Assessment of Reading Test (DART): Decoding

q1.value: Dynamic Assessment of Reading Test (DART): Decoding

q2.value: Christopher Dixon, Emily Oxley, Hannah Nash

q3.value: Twenty-five percent of children leave primary school unable to read well (Save the Children, 2014) and low literacy is related to a range of poor life outcomes (Morrisroe, 2014). Early identification of children at-risk of reading difficulties is of paramount importance. The number of children with English as an Additional Language (EAL) (20.1% in 2016; Schools, pupils and their characteristics: January 2016 SFR 20/2016 DfE) and children living in poverty (DWP, 2015/2016) continues to rise. Children from these backgrounds are at a disadvantage entering formal education because their pre-school environment can lead to weaknesses in the English language skills which underpin reading development (e.g., Chaippe, Siegel & Wade-Woolley, 2009; D’Angiulli, Siegel & Hertzman, 2004; D’Angiulli, Siegel & Maggi, 2004; Hoff, 2015). Traditional screening measures are static and assess existing knowledge, which is a product of a child’s capacity to learn and their language experience. If a child performs poorly on a static measure, it is not possible to determine whether this is due to environmental factors or whether the child has an underlying reading disorder. The DART project will establish whether dynamic learning tasks (Grigorenko, 2009) can improve screening for reading disorders. Specifically, dynamic learning tasks measure children’s response to novel teaching as opposed to their pre-existing knowledge. In this study, a computerised dynamic assessment of decoding will be administered to children in Reception (age 4-5). A major aim of the study is to assess whether performance on a dynamic assessment (time 1) predicts growth in word reading and reading disability status approximately one year later (time 2).

q4.value:
1.	A computerised dynamic test of decoding will not be strongly positively correlated with socioeconomic status (SES) or English language proficiency (EAL status) at the first time point.
2.	The experimental dynamic test will predict growth in reading between the two time points. 
3.	The dynamic test will achieve clinically acceptable levels of accuracy in identifying children with a reading disorder at the second time point.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study will employ a between-subject (EAL vs. non-EAL) and within-subject (time 1 – time 2) repeated measures design. All participants assessed at time 1 will be followed up at time 2. The dynamic test of decoding will be administered at time 1 only. At time 2 approximately one year later, performance on a standardised measure of word reading accuracy will be used to determine which children fulfil criteria for a reading disorder.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data will be collected from children in Reception classes (age 4-5) in participating primary schools in Leeds. Seven primary schools which participated in a previous work packages of the DART project (word learning in Year 4 children and orthographic learning in Year 3 children) will take part in the present study. Given the project’s hypotheses concerning relationships between the dynamic test and SES and EAL, attempts were made to recruit schools with a combination of large/small EAL populations from areas of lower and higher SES. All seven pre-recruited schools will also participate in the present study with Reception-age children. In the event that schools drop out of the project, additional schools may be recruited.
At the point of data collection there are no exclusionary recruitment criteria and thus the sample will contain children with varying degrees of special educational needs. The same participants will be assessed at time 1 and time 2 (approximately 12 months apart).

q13.value: The study will aim to recruit enough participants in order to carry out sufficiently powered sensitivity/specificity estimates (in order to identify children with decoding difficulties at time 2). Based on prevalence estimates we would expect to find 10-17% of the sample have a word-level reading disorder. Peterson et al. (2016) achieved a sensitivity estimate of .92 with their dynamic task of decoding. According to Bujong and Adnan (2016), with a disorder prevalence of 10% and a sensitivity estimate of .90 we would need a sample containing 12 affected and 120 unaffected cases (.89). Even with a lower sensitivity estimate of .80 we would need 20 affected and 200 unaffected cases (.80 power). We will aim to recruit approximately 300 children to allow for potential attrition.

question.value:
1. Coloured Progressive Matrices (CPM; Pearson, 2008). The CPM is a nonverbal screening measure of general ability. It is appropriate for use with individuals from culturally or linguistically diverse backgrounds. Examinees are presented with a series of diagrammatic puzzles and asked to select one of six solutions to ‘fit’ the puzzle.

2. British Picture Vocabulary Scale-III (BPVS; Dunn, Dunn & NFER, 2009). The BPVS-III is a measure of receptive vocabulary breadth knowledge in which examinees are presented with a series of test plates containing four colour pictures and are asked to identify the picture corresponding to a stimulus word spoken by the examiner.

3. York Assessment for Reading Comprehension Early Reading (YARC; Hulme et al., 2011). All four phonological awareness measures of the YARC will be administered:
•	Letter Sound Knowledge: a measure of children’s alphabetic knowledge consisting of a Core test (17 letters and digraphs) and an Extended test (all 26 letters and 6 digraphs). Children are shown a series of printed letters and digraphs and asked ‘what sound does this letter make?’
•	Early Word Recognition: a measure of reading ability. Children attempt to read a series of 30 real words of increasing difficulty (cat, in, … biscuit, giant)

4. Phonological Assessment Battery-Primary 2nd Edition (PhAB; Gibbs & Bodman, 2014). Three subtests from the PhAB will be used, including:
•	Alliteration: a measure of the ability to detect whether two words share the same initial phoneme. Children are presented illustrated colour plates depicting three objects and asked to indicate which two words begin with the same sound (well, peg, pot). 
•	Blending: a measure of the ability to blend individual sounds into spoken words. Children are asked to blend phonemes to make words, for example /c/ /a/ /t/ = cat. 
•	Naming Speed: a measure of rapid automatised naming (RAN). In Picture Naming, children are presented with a matrix of randomly repeating rows of illustrations (ball, hat, door, table, box) and asked to name all items as quickly as possible. A child's score is how long they take to name all items.

5. Dynamic Assessment
The dynamic assessment is a computerised adaptation of Gellert and Elbro (2017) in which children learn novel letters and their sounds. The task is designed and administered using PsychoPy (including illustrations, visual stimuli, and aural feedback) and consists of three phases:
•	Paired-associate learning of symbols and sounds. In this learning phase, children learn three letter-like symbols and their sounds to criterion. Feedback is provided.
•	Blending. Children are trained in blending the three ‘letters’ to make ‘words’ before attempting to do this themselves. Feedback is provided for the blending test items.
•	Reading. Children attempt to read ‘words’ made up of the three symbols. No feedback is provided.

The posttest score is a combination of scores on Blending test items and Reading. 

6. Predictive Early Assessment of Reading and Language (PEARL; Petersen & Spencer, 2014) 
The project will also assess the predictive accuracy of an additional non-computerised dynamic assessment of decoding. The PEARL consists of a test-teach-test procedure in which children are asked to decode four non-words (tad, nad, zad, kad). In a training phase, children are instructed on how to pronounce each individual letter, blend the sounds together, and read the nonwords. In addition to pre- and posttest scores, a learning score (0-4) also captures children’s facility with the task.

Correlational analysis will be carried out to test the first hypothesis (lack of strong relationships between performance on the dynamic assessment and SES / EAL status). 
Hierarchical linear regression models will be run to assess the second hypothesis. In these models, components of early word reading (phonemic awareness, rapid automatised naming, as well as an early word reading autoregressor) and dynamic assessment performance will be used to predict YARC Early Word Recognition at time 2. 

For hypothesis three, children will be classified as reading disabled or typically developing at time 2. Criteria for reading disabled status will be those children scoring at least -1SD below the mean on a standardised measure of reading (YARC Early Word Recognition), or children scoring in the bottom 15% of the sample. Hierarchical logistic regression and area under ROC curve analysis will be used to calculate the classification accuracy of the dynamic assessment, along with calculations of sensitivity and specificity. Accuracy of the dynamic learning task and the static measures will be compared using the method of DeLong, DeLong and Clarke-Pearson (1988) to calculate the Standard Error of the Area Under the Curve (AUC) and the difference between two AUCs (this will be done in R using the pROC package). Following this, it will be assessed to what extent combining the dynamic and static measures improves prediction by comparing the log likelihood statistics and the ROC values.

Children with a dyslexic profile will be identified as those who score below average (-1SD) and/or who are within the lowest 15% of the sample on the test of word reading at time 2 of the study.

q24.value: We aim to compare the predictive accuracy of our own computerised dynamic assessment and the PEARL (Petersen & Spencer, 2014).

registration_responses.q1: Dynamic Assessment of Reading Test (DART): Decoding
registration_responses.q2: Christopher Dixon, Emily Oxley, Hannah Nash
registration_responses.q3: Twenty-five percent of children leave primary school unable to read well (Save the Children, 2014) and low literacy is related to a range of poor life outcomes (Morrisroe, 2014). Early identification of children at-risk of reading difficulties is of paramount importance. The number of children with English as an Additional Language (EAL) (20.1% in 2016; Schools, pupils and their characteristics: January 2016 SFR 20/2016 DfE) and children living in poverty (DWP, 2015/2016) continues to rise. Children from these backgrounds are at a disadvantage entering formal education because their pre-school environment can lead to weaknesses in the English language skills which underpin reading development (e.g., Chaippe, Siegel & Wade-Woolley, 2009; D’Angiulli, Siegel & Hertzman, 2004; D’Angiulli, Siegel & Maggi, 2004; Hoff, 2015). Traditional screening measures are static and assess existing knowledge, which is a product of a child’s capacity to learn and their language experience. If a child performs poorly on a static measure, it is not possible to determine whether this is due to environmental factors or whether the child has an underlying reading disorder. The DART project will establish whether dynamic learning tasks (Grigorenko, 2009) can improve screening for reading disorders. Specifically, dynamic learning tasks measure children’s response to novel teaching as opposed to their pre-existing knowledge. In this study, a computerised dynamic assessment of decoding will be administered to children in Reception (age 4-5). A major aim of the study is to assess whether performance on a dynamic assessment (time 1) predicts growth in word reading and reading disability status approximately one year later (time 2).
registration_responses.q4:
1.	A computerised dynamic test of decoding will not be strongly positively correlated with socioeconomic status (SES) or English language proficiency (EAL status) at the first time point.
2.	The experimental dynamic test will predict growth in reading between the two time points. 
3.	The dynamic test will achieve clinically acceptable levels of accuracy in identifying children with a reading disorder at the second time point.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: The study will aim to recruit enough participants in order to carry out sufficiently powered sensitivity/specificity estimates (in order to identify children with decoding difficulties at time 2). Based on prevalence estimates we would expect to find 10-17% of the sample have a word-level reading disorder. Peterson et al. (2016) achieved a sensitivity estimate of .92 with their dynamic task of decoding. According to Bujong and Adnan (2016), with a disorder prevalence of 10% and a sensitivity estimate of .90 we would need a sample containing 12 affected and 120 unaffected cases (.89). Even with a lower sensitivity estimate of .80 we would need 20 affected and 200 unaffected cases (.80 power). We will aim to recruit approximately 300 children to allow for potential attrition.
registration_responses.q24: We aim to compare the predictive accuracy of our own computerised dynamic assessment and the PEARL (Petersen & Spencer, 2014).
registration_responses.q8.question: The study will employ a between-subject (EAL vs. non-EAL) and within-subject (time 1 – time 2) repeated measures design. All participants assessed at time 1 will be followed up at time 2. The dynamic test of decoding will be administered at time 1 only. At time 2 approximately one year later, performance on a standardised measure of word reading accuracy will be used to determine which children fulfil criteria for a reading disorder.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Data will be collected from children in Reception classes (age 4-5) in participating primary schools in Leeds. Seven primary schools which participated in a previous work packages of the DART project (word learning in Year 4 children and orthographic learning in Year 3 children) will take part in the present study. Given the project’s hypotheses concerning relationships between the dynamic test and SES and EAL, attempts were made to recruit schools with a combination of large/small EAL populations from areas of lower and higher SES. All seven pre-recruited schools will also participate in the present study with Reception-age children. In the event that schools drop out of the project, additional schools may be recruited.
At the point of data collection there are no exclusionary recruitment criteria and thus the sample will contain children with varying degrees of special educational needs. The same participants will be assessed at time 1 and time 2 (approximately 12 months apart).
registration_responses.q17.question:
1. Coloured Progressive Matrices (CPM; Pearson, 2008). The CPM is a nonverbal screening measure of general ability. It is appropriate for use with individuals from culturally or linguistically diverse backgrounds. Examinees are presented with a series of diagrammatic puzzles and asked to select one of six solutions to ‘fit’ the puzzle.

2. British Picture Vocabulary Scale-III (BPVS; Dunn, Dunn & NFER, 2009). The BPVS-III is a measure of receptive vocabulary breadth knowledge in which examinees are presented with a series of test plates containing four colour pictures and are asked to identify the picture corresponding to a stimulus word spoken by the examiner.

3. York Assessment for Reading Comprehension Early Reading (YARC; Hulme et al., 2011). All four phonological awareness measures of the YARC will be administered:
•	Letter Sound Knowledge: a measure of children’s alphabetic knowledge consisting of a Core test (17 letters and digraphs) and an Extended test (all 26 letters and 6 digraphs). Children are shown a series of printed letters and digraphs and asked ‘what sound does this letter make?’
•	Early Word Recognition: a measure of reading ability. Children attempt to read a series of 30 real words of increasing difficulty (cat, in, … biscuit, giant)

4. Phonological Assessment Battery-Primary 2nd Edition (PhAB; Gibbs & Bodman, 2014). Three subtests from the PhAB will be used, including:
•	Alliteration: a measure of the ability to detect whether two words share the same initial phoneme. Children are presented illustrated colour plates depicting three objects and asked to indicate which two words begin with the same sound (well, peg, pot). 
•	Blending: a measure of the ability to blend individual sounds into spoken words. Children are asked to blend phonemes to make words, for example /c/ /a/ /t/ = cat. 
•	Naming Speed: a measure of rapid automatised naming (RAN). In Picture Naming, children are presented with a matrix of randomly repeating rows of illustrations (ball, hat, door, table, box) and asked to name all items as quickly as possible. A child's score is how long they take to name all items.

5. Dynamic Assessment
The dynamic assessment is a computerised adaptation of Gellert and Elbro (2017) in which children learn novel letters and their sounds. The task is designed and administered using PsychoPy (including illustrations, visual stimuli, and aural feedback) and consists of three phases:
•	Paired-associate learning of symbols and sounds. In this learning phase, children learn three letter-like symbols and their sounds to criterion. Feedback is provided.
•	Blending. Children are trained in blending the three ‘letters’ to make ‘words’ before attempting to do this themselves. Feedback is provided for the blending test items.
•	Reading. Children attempt to read ‘words’ made up of the three symbols. No feedback is provided.

The posttest score is a combination of scores on Blending test items and Reading. 

6. Predictive Early Assessment of Reading and Language (PEARL; Petersen & Spencer, 2014) 
The project will also assess the predictive accuracy of an additional non-computerised dynamic assessment of decoding. The PEARL consists of a test-teach-test procedure in which children are asked to decode four non-words (tad, nad, zad, kad). In a training phase, children are instructed on how to pronounce each individual letter, blend the sounds together, and read the nonwords. In addition to pre- and posttest scores, a learning score (0-4) also captures children’s facility with the task.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Correlational analysis will be carried out to test the first hypothesis (lack of strong relationships between performance on the dynamic assessment and SES / EAL status). 
Hierarchical linear regression models will be run to assess the second hypothesis. In these models, components of early word reading (phonemic awareness, rapid automatised naming, as well as an early word reading autoregressor) and dynamic assessment performance will be used to predict YARC Early Word Recognition at time 2. 

For hypothesis three, children will be classified as reading disabled or typically developing at time 2. Criteria for reading disabled status will be those children scoring at least -1SD below the mean on a standardised measure of reading (YARC Early Word Recognition), or children scoring in the bottom 15% of the sample. Hierarchical logistic regression and area under ROC curve analysis will be used to calculate the classification accuracy of the dynamic assessment, along with calculations of sensitivity and specificity. Accuracy of the dynamic learning task and the static measures will be compared using the method of DeLong, DeLong and Clarke-Pearson (1988) to calculate the Standard Error of the Area Under the Curve (AUC) and the difference between two AUCs (this will be done in R using the pROC package). Following this, it will be assessed to what extent combining the dynamic and static measures improves prediction by comparing the log likelihood statistics and the ROC values.

Children with a dyslexic profile will be identified as those who score below average (-1SD) and/or who are within the lowest 15% of the sample on the test of word reading at time 2 of the study.

attributes.title: Confirmation Bias´ effect on interpretation of interrogation
attributes.description: For my master thesis, a survey will be conducted to examine if confirmation bias in police investigations effect the interpretation of suspect interrogation.

summary.value:
Confirmation bias effects on interpretation of interrogation. 

     Several studies have been conducted to explore the effects of confirmation bias within the justice system, and factors such as time pressure, demands for high clearance rate, and media attention increases the risk of confirmation bias during investigations and interrogations (Findley & Scott, 2006). Confirmation bias may result in misinterpretation of evidence (Ask, Rebelius & Granhag, 2008) and create a guilt-confirming investigation (Rassin et al, 2010), which also affects the conduction of interrogations. The perceived credibility of suspects statement decreases while the risk of using confrontational interrogation methods with leading and guilt-driven questions increases (Powell, Hughes Scholes & Sharman, 2012), which in turn can induce false confessions and wrongfully imprisonment of an innocent suspect (Hartwig, Granhag, Strömwall & Vrij, 2005). Even though much research within the field of legal psychology has explored the effects of confirmation bias, they often focus on either investigations or interrogations. They can almost be categorized as two different fields of research, even though interrogations are a vital part of the investigation, and to my knowledge, these two fields rarely been linked together. Therefore, this research will examine whether the initial focus in the investigation (biased or not) affects the interpretation of the interrogation.

Method

Participants 
     To conduct this research, a survey (created in Qualtrics) will be distributed to two of the authors´ contacts within the police force who agreed to pass the survey forward to their colleagues, as well as teachers within the Swedish police academy. The survey will also be published in a Facebook-group with police officers as members. 
An a priori power analysis was computed to test the required sample size. In previous research on bias in investigations (Ask, Rebelius & Granhag, 2008; Fahsing & Ask, 2016; O´Brien, 2009) and interrogations/interviews (Hill et al; Kassin et al), effect sizes have ranged between 0.45 and 0.95. Specifically, a previous study using the same stimulus material as the present study (Ask & Granhag, 2005) found an effect size of d = 0.52, (i.e., a medium effect according to Cohens guidelines; Cohen, 1988). Given a power level of .80, α = .05 and the expected effect size of d = 0.52, a total sample size of 120 participants is required as a minimum. If a sample size of 120 participants is not met within the time window available for data collection, a sensitivity test will be computed using the actual number of participants and same values of power (0.8) and alpha (0.05), to calculate the smallest detectable effect size. 


Procedure and Materials
     Besides information about voluntary participation, anonymity, and instructions, the survey contains a vignette depicting a homicide case (based on Ask & Granhag, 2005), where the police found the victim dead in her apartment. Another woman was also found in the apartment and hence became the prime suspect. The participants will randomly be assigned into one of two groups; the ´suspect guilty´ condition will get a motive of jealousy, while the ´alternative suspect´ condition will be introduced to an alternative suspect, a man who previously threatened the victim. All participants will then rate their perception of the prime suspect probability of guilt (e.g., How likely is it that the prime suspect is guilty? How strong do you consider the support is at the time, for the suspect guilt?), before reading a draft from an interrogation of the prime suspect, which will be held constant for all participants. After a repeated measure of guilt, all participants will rate their perception of the interrogation through questions about guilt ( i.e., to what extent do you think the interrogation provides support for the suspects guilt?), components defining the interrogation method (e.g., to what extent do you think the interrogation was manipulative? To what extent do you think the interrogator asked open-ended questions?), and the suspect statement (e.g., to what extent do you think the information given by the suspect is reliable?). All questions will be answered on a 1-7 point scale (1 = not at all, 7 = to a very high degree). Finally, participants will be asked about gender, age, and experience within police investigations and interrogations, before they are thanked for their participation and informed that the case and interrogation were fictive and produced for the current study. See the uploaded file for the survey material.  

Hypothesis
1.	Participants in the ´suspect guilty´ condition will interpret the interrogation as more incriminating than participants in the ´alternative suspect´ condition.
2.	Participants in the suspect guilty condition will rate the interrogation as better conducted (e.g., less manipulative, less guilt presumptive) than participants in the alternative suspect´ condition.
3.	Participants in the ´suspect guilty´ condition will ascribe more guilt towards the prime suspect after reading the suspect interrogation, than participants in ´alternative suspects´ condition. 
4.	Participants in the ´suspect guilty´ condition will display a stronger increase in ratings of the suspects´ guilt after having read the suspect interrogation compared with participants in the ´alternative suspects´ condition. 

Analysis
     Before data analysis to test the hypotheses, the internal reliability of questions intended to measure the same underlying construct will be controlled through Cronbach´s alpha, and indexes will be calculated. Given that all requirements are met, the following analysis methods will be used. A Significance level of .05 will be used for all significance testing. 
To test Hypothesis 1, an independent t-test will be conducted using experimental condition (suspect guilty vs. alternative suspect) as the independent variable and participants´ ratings of the extent to which the interrogation indicates that the suspect is guilty, as the dependent variable. The hypothesis will be considered supported if participants in the suspect guilty condition make significantly higher guilt ratings than participants in the alternative suspect condition.  
     For Hypothesis 2, a principal component analysis (PCA) will be conducted to check the relatedness and correlation between all the measured aspects of the interrogation (i.e., interrogation method and suspects´ statement) in order to identify which variables to combine into index variables to use in the main analysis. A MANOVA will then be conducted to measure the overall effect on participants´ perception of the interrogation, using condition (suspect guilty vs alternative suspects) as the independent variable, and the identified variables of the suspect interrogation, as dependent variables. If a significant multivariate effect is detected, univariate tests will be calculated to identify how each variable differed between the two conditions. Hypothesis 2 will be considered supported if participants in the guilty suspect condition rate the interrogation as better conducted than participants in the alternative suspect condition. 
To test Hypothesis 3, an independent t-test will be conducted using experimental condition (suspect guilty vs alternative suspects) as the independent variable and participants ratings of the suspect´s guilt after the interrogation as the dependent variable. The hypothesis will be considered supported if participants in the suspect guilty condition make significantly higher guilt ratings than participants in the alternative suspect condition.
     With participants´ pre- and post-interrogation ratings of the suspects´ guilt as the dependent variable, a mixed ANOVA will be conducted to test Hypothesis 4. The analysis will use experimental condition (suspect guilty vs alternative suspect) as the between-subject variable and time (before vs after interrogation) as the within-subject variable. The hypothesis will be considered supported if (a) the Condition x Time interaction is significant and (b) the increase in guilt ratings is larger in the suspect guilty condition than in the alternative suspect condition. 

References

Ask, K., & Granhag, P. A. (2005). Motivational sources of confirmation bias in criminal 
investigations: The need for cognitive closure. Journal of Investigative Psychology and Offender Profiling, 2, 43–63.

Ask, K., Rebelius, A., & Granhag, P.A. (2008). The ´elasticity´ of criminal evidence: A 
moderator of investigator bias. Applied Cognitive Psychology, 22, 1245-1259. 

Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical power analysis for the behavioral sciences. Hillsdale, NJ: Erlbaum.

Fahsing, I., & Ask, K. (2016). The making of an expert detective: the role of experience in 
English and Norwegian police officers´ investigative decision-making. Psychology, Crime & Law, 22:3, 203-223. DOI: 10.1080/1068316X.2016.1077249

Findley, K.A., & Scott, M. S. (2006). The multiple dimensions of tunnel vision in criminal cases. 
Wisconsin Law Review, 291, 291-397. 

Hartwig, M., Granhag, P. A., Strömwall, L. A., & Vrij, A. (2005). Detecting deception via 
strategic disclosure of evidence. Law and Human Behavior, 29, 469–484. http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s10979-005-5521-x

Hill, C., Memon, A., & McGeorge, P. (2008). The role of confirmation bias in suspect 
interviews: A systematic evaluation. Legal and Criminological Psychology, 13, 357–371.

Kassin, S. M., Goldstein, C. C., & Savitsky, K. (2003). Behavioural Confirmation in the 
Interrogation Room: On the Dangers of Presuming Guilt. Law and Human Behaviour, 27 (2), 187–203.

O´Brien, B. (2009). Prime suspect: An examination of factors that aggravate and counteract 
confirmation bias in criminal investigations. Psychology, Public Policy, and Law, 15, 315-334.

Powell, M., Hughes Scholes, C. H., & Sharman, S. J. (2012). Skill in Interviewing Reduces 
Confirmation Bias. Journal of Investigative Psychology and Offender Profiling, 9, 126–134

Rassin, E., Eerland, A., & Kuijpers, I. (2010). Let´s Find the Evidence: An Analogue Study of 
Confirmation Bias in Criminal Investigations. Journal of Investigative Psychologu and Offender Profiling, 7, 231-246.
